answers.a: Kaolin clay is a naturally occurring hydrated aluminium silicate mineral (mainly kaolinite), used as the food additive E559 (aluminium silicate). It’s a fine, white, inert powder formed by the weathering of feldspar-rich rocks.
In foods (as E559), it’s used mainly as an anti‑caking and release agent in powdered products and as a processing aid; outside foods, it’s widely used in ceramics, paper, rubber, and cosmetics.
It occurs worldwide in deposits formed by weathering of granite/feldspar; major sources include China (Gaoling), the southeastern United States (Georgia), the UK (Cornwall), and Brazil.

answers.q: how much kaolin clay per pound of soap
answers.a: A common usage rate is about 0.5–1 teaspoon per pound of oils (roughly 1–3 g per 454 g), pre-dispersed in a little water or oil; higher amounts can make soap feel draggy or more drying.

answers.q: is kaolin clay good for skin
answers.a: Cosmetic‑grade kaolin is a mild, fine clay that can absorb excess oil and add slip, so it’s commonly used in masks and powders; it’s generally well tolerated, but overuse may be drying—patch test if you have very dry or sensitive skin.
